properties.name: Agua Prieta Migrant Resource Center
properties.description: Posted by Steev   One of 3 migrant centers set up on the Mexican side of the Arizona/Sonora borderline (the others are in Naco and Nogales). The centers provide food, water, medical attention and information to migrants who have just been deported from the U.S. They also engage in documenting abuses perpetrated on detained migrants by U.S. border patrol personnel, and help the Mexican consulate arrange travel for migrants back to their homes elsewhere in Mexico.

properties.name: Anapra
properties.description: Posted by Steev   At this spot one can look through a chain-link fence from a dusty parking lot in New Mexico to a crowded colonia in Juarez, Chihuahua, called Rancho Anapra, full of makeshift shacks and dirt streets. Every year for Day of the Dead, a cross-border mass happens. I attended the mass in 2004, on the Mexican side, but had never been to the U.S. side of this spot. Up on a nearby hill you can see Cristo Rey, a giant stone cross that marks the corner of Texas, New Mexico, and Chihuahua.

properties.name: Border Field State Park
properties.description: Posted by Steev This place is a beautiful natural area that is being heavily impacted by U.S. border enforcement activities.

properties.name: Casa Puente
properties.description: Posted by Steev   1009 N Florence, el paso, txThe HQ of Project Puente, which organizes trips to the border to teach various groups about the issues and concerns there.

properties.name: Columbus, New Mexico
properties.description: Posted by Steev  One of the few border crossings between Mexico and New Mexico, Columbus was attacked and partially burned by Pancho Villa\'s army in 1916, in response to the U.S. supporting the Carranza regime in Mexico, and to the U.S. selling defective bullets to Villa. This marked the first time since the War of 1812 that U.S. territory was attacked by another country. A punitive search force was dispatched into Mexico by the U.S. in response, but they never found Villa.

properties.name: El Paso/Juarez - Santa Fe border port
properties.description: Posted by Steev One of several border crossings between El Paso, Texas and Ciudad Juarez, Chihuahua. I first visited this spot in 2004 to film an international march and rally to demand justice regarding the hundreds of murdered women in Juarez.

properties.name: Friendship Park
properties.description: Posted by Steev   A cross-border communion happens every Sunday here at the border wall, at least until the Border Patrol stops it, which they seem to want to do starting about 2 weeks ago. photo by Jill Holslin.

properties.name: Imperial Dunes
properties.description: Posted by Steev  As part of the Secure Fence Act, new border wall has been constructed in the last year and now slices through these waves of sand that straddle the international boundary.

properties.name: Jacumba
properties.description: Posted by Steev   The small, almost deserted-looking town of Jacumba is split by the border wall, which stretches through the little valley and up into the mountains on both ends.

properties.name: Mexicali, Baja California Norte
properties.description: Posted by Steev   The capital of Baja California Norte, Mexicali is a city of 1.5 million residents and hundreds of maquiladoras, the factories that produce products for export by foreign companies. Situated just south of the California\'s Imperial Valley, Mexicali is also a prime site to witness issues of cross-border environmental and economic imbalance.

properties.name: Naco Migrant Center
properties.description: Posted by Steev  One of 3 migrant centers set up on the Mexican side of the Arizona/Sonora borderline (the others are in Agua Prieta and Nogales). The centers provide food, water, medical attention and information to migrants who have just been deported from the U.S. They also engage in documenting abuses perpetrated on detained migrants by U.S. border patrol personnel, and help the Mexican consulate arrange travel for migrants back to their homes elsewhere in Mexico.

properties.name: Rio Bosque Wetlands Park
properties.description: Posted by Steev   This is a rare spot of reconstructed nature in an area where almost every piece of land is highly managed, altered from its original condition, and controlled, especially along the Rio Grande. Now this park is site to a litlte more control in the form of a section of border fence which Homeland Security contractors Kiewit broke ground on in mid-December and are now close to finishing. At the start of construction Judy Ackerman sat down in front of the machines and delayed construction for 8 hours - the first act of civil disobedience against building of the border wall.

properties.name: Senator MacCain's Office
properties.description: Posted by Steev  A frequent place for activists to demonstrate and rally for change, Arizona Senator John McCain\'s Tucson office is here. On January 21, 2009, Border Action Network held a rally outside to call on the Senator, newly-inaugurated President Obama, and all relevant officials to bring about change in immigration and border policy.

properties.name: Site of the 2007 No Borders Camp
properties.description: Posted by Steev   This is the spot where hundreds of activists gathered on both sides of the border for a week in November 2007 to protest U.S. border militarization. Today, a new second wall makes it impossible to get near the spot from the Mexican side, and a new fortified fence stands where once the activists served breakfast to each other across the line.
